title: Why is everyone so mean to me for being new?
body: Im level 14 new to the game still, ive been told to get cancer and die, ive been told to go kill myself, ive been told many different horribly mean things but i dont understand why? Im still trying to learn the game and yet people are such jerks to me? How am i supposed to learn anything in this kind of environment? Why cant people just be nice and help me learn instead of being such a jerk? Or i get people against me who are lvl 30 with full runes, more masteries and have been playing a ton longer then i have, yet when they beat me instead of helping me learn what i did wrong they try to trash talk and rub it in my face. What is with this community?

replies.body:
I'm completely confident that the majority of players are pretty decent folks. But even if only 10% of league players are assholes on short fuses, that means you'll hit one about every game on average. And it only takes one toxic player to change the atmosphere of a game from fun to unpleasant. Just ignore the trolls and do your best.

By the way, a lot of people forget that once you've reached the ranking appropriate to your skill level, your win rate will be around 50%. That means you'll loose about half your games. Loosing isn't the best feeling in the world, but it's part of the game.

I think the community comes through a little better on the forums, because the 10% assholes can get downvoted to oblivion and drowned out, whereas in-game, one toxic player can often send other players into a mood where they're toxic, too.

I have a couple pieces of advice:

1. As others have said, mute, mute, mute. Do it as soon as the person makes a negative comment, even if it's not about you. It's just not worth the risk of them ruining your game and you can always unmute them. Some people will say how that's bad because of communication but
  - That's not really important until high level play (at least gold) - before then all you need are pings.
  - Most people who are toxic don't have anything valuable to say anyway.
  - Even if they did, it's not worth getting your game ruined for a small advantage in coordination.
2. Play in groups. In the post-game screen, anybody who was nice to you, *especially in games where there was a mean person,* add them as a friend. Now instead of going solo queue you can play with a couple people you know will be nice. Don't be afraid to remove them if they aren't always nice.
  - Even if you can't find a group of 5 nice people, knowing you'll have somebody or a couple somebodies who will  who will have your back is super nice. 
3. Do your part. Report the jerks. If someone is getting yelled at in your game, let the jerk know that's not okay. They may turn their attention to you, so be ready to mute them and remind your teammate that they can do the same.
4. Don't engage. If someone's just raging at you, or one of your teammates, (almost) never talk to the rager. You'll almost always end up acting defensive, which just paints a bigger target on you. Instead, focus on keeping your positive teammates positive. "You haven't muted him yet?" or "Hey, don't yell at my teammate" <- (said to a positive petson who was about to start yelling at a rager) gets your message across just as effectively.

You're welcome to add me (I may ask who you are if I forget your summoner name from this thread) and I'll find a way to play with you and teach you a bit :)

Hey there fellow aspiring summoner,

As someone who was also a very new player at one point (I've been playing for around a year on and off though frankly I still am very, very bad) I know how harsh  a lot of the player base is, not just to new players, but just anyone in general (though new players get picked on worse for the fact that they're new).

They do it for multiple reasons, all of them very wrong: 

1.) They've been flamed many times before and some people can't deal with it and turn that frustration on others whenever they can.

2.) They get fed and very ahead of the new players easily simply because they are more experienced and then feel like they were gods all along.

3.) When it's your teammates who do it, it's because they simply assume new players will have the same amount of knowledge as they do and find the fact that they make mistakes people who they regularly play with wouldn't normally do unacceptable and instead of trying to give tips to the player and encourage improvement, they flame them and only make things worse.

As someone who's been through this I know this can turn people away from the game for good. Or at least make you doubt in yourself and put your mood down. What you can do, is simply try to ignore them and focus on your own game. If they keep their bad attitude up, you can hit the tab button, mouse over their champion portrait and hit the "mute" button and report them for "negative attitude" or "Verbal Abuse" at the end of the game If they are a problem, the system will eventually punish them and attempt to correct their behavior.

I should also say, never let all the toxcity get to your head. Not only can it affect your performance but it can also frustrate you and lead you into being toxic yourself. It really does happen, I've let it get in my head before and I have been toxic myself to other toxic players harassing me. I try not to do it and whenever I come close to it I think of the old quote: "Never let an Idiot drag you to his level for he will beat you with experience".

Lastly, I'd like to say that if you really, really like this game then don't give up on it It really can be fun at times and when you can tell you've improved as time passes on it feels pretty nice!

I'm not the best player around, but feel free to add me in game if you want and I'll play games with you if I can and try to help you out with the game as far as what little game knowledge I have!

Your best bet is to try and meet people.  I was lucky enough to meet a few people through friends, and I've played the last few seasons with them.  PUGs are just too much of a grab bag to reliably have a good experience, but if you meet some nice people you'll have fun playing for years.

I don't know if the boards here are a good way to try and meet people if you don't know anyone IRL who plays, but Reddit can be pretty good sometimes.

I played bots until I hit level 30. In that environment you're more likely to meet players around your skill level and people who know how to play who are more willing to teach newer players.

I know beginner bots is probably too easy but at your summoner level intermediate bots might actually be a worthy challenge to you. At your summoner level you usually will get 1-2 teammates who feed horrendously so it will still feel like a PvP game. So you will still be in a position where you will need to carry some dead weight and it can be a good learning experience. There are some hacks you can pull to cheat the game into winning if you cannot out-muscle the bots. Split pushing is your friend.

I only recently started playing PvP maybe 3 months ago. Played bots for 2+ years. You don't have to stay in bots as long as I did but playing bots did wonders for my mechanics. Heck, I play on a touchpad and my mechanics are more refined than a lot of the people I meet in solo queue. Bots are great at teaching you mechanics, timing and how to dodge skill shots effectively. But they do make you learn some bad habits. Like chasing for kills, going places that aren't warded and cheap tricking the AI via ambushes because they never learn from mistakes.

If you do play intermediate there are some tricks. Like in the loading screen you can predict where each bot will go based on where their portrait is. Read from left to right and say Bottom, Top, Middle, Bottom, Top. So if the bots are as follows: Ezreal, Blitzcrank, Vladimir, Sona & Lux you won't be caught off guard by seeing Lux and Blitzcrank in the top lane. At 11:00 the bots do a lane swap. One of the top laners (or bottom laners) will roam into mid lane. You can make a pick off if you plan for this. The bots won't ult unless there is a kill to be had. They won't ult unless you have under 20% hp, so if Karthus bot is in the game back whenever you have 1/3 of your health. Late game the bots will group up in whatever lane has been pushes the hardest. If top lane is at inhibitor tower and mid lane and bot lane are still at the outer towers the bots will 5 man group at top and neglect mid lane and top lane. In PvP you want to rush top lane but in bots you actually want to play passively top lane and shove in mid lane and bottom lane. The bots will split up once one of the other lanes has been pushed in as hard as top lane was. And bots still play like Bronze tier players, they would much rather 5 man pursue a low health champion than defend their Nexus from winions.

Some tips I can offer tho, practice csing. Load up a custom game,  and practice gettingr every minion in every wave before the 5min mark. Then practice just last hitting the minions without losing one. Do this with all the champions you are interested in playing,  and then practice forcing the lane to freeze or push the way you want while playing against a bot.  Being able to get those things down will help you a lot. 
Then focus on poking a bot down while not losing cs, or 
taking too much poke back. 

Early laning mechanics are extremely important for every player to know,  and can make such a large difference in a game. 

If your interested in what to build on a champ check out lolking, solomid,  and other guides. They will even help You figure out How to set up a rune page and masteries. 

Lastly. Do NOT worry about the runes tell you can buy lvl 3 ones. Otherwise you will just be wasting ip on things you will never use.
